Borshch

Jump to Recipe

Borshch is a beloved Eastern European dish, particularly cherished in Ukraine, for its vibrant color and hearty flavors. This iconic beet soup is not just a meal; it’s a cultural symbol, often bringing families together around the table. With its base of tender beets, which give the soup its signature deep red hue, Borshch is packed with nutritious vegetables like cabbage, potatoes, and carrots. This recipe will guide you through creating a traditional Borshch from scratch, using simple ingredients that are easy to find. Whether you’re looking to warm up on a chilly day or impress guests with a unique dish, this Borshch recipe is sure to delight. Join us as we dive into the rich flavors and comforting aroma of this classic dish, perfect for any occasion and ideal for meal prep!

Ingredients

beets

Choose firm, unblemished beets for the best flavor. If you can't find fresh beets, canned beets can be used, but reduce cooking time. Roasting beets before grating can enhance their sweetness.

cabbage

Use green or savoy cabbage for a sweeter flavor. If you want a crunchier texture, add the cabbage towards the end of cooking. For a lighter alternative, you can substitute with kale or collard greens.

potatoes

Russet or Yukon Gold potatoes work best for their creaminess. If you're looking for a lower-carb option, consider using cauliflower instead.

carrots

Choose bright, firm carrots for optimum sweetness. If you want to enhance the flavor, try roasting them before adding to the soup. If you don’t have fresh carrots, you can substitute with frozen carrots.

onion

Use yellow or white onions for a more balanced flavor; red onions can be used for a milder taste. To enhance sweetness, sauté the onions slowly until caramelized.

garlic

Fresh garlic is best, but garlic powder can be used in a pinch (1/8 tsp per clove). To mellow the flavor, roast the garlic before adding it to the pot.

tomato paste

If you don’t have tomato paste, you can use canned diced tomatoes (but reduce the broth slightly). For added flavor, consider adding a splash of vinegar or lemon juice.

vegetable broth

Homemade broth is always best, but store-bought is convenient. For a richer flavor, consider using low-sodium broth or add a splash of soy sauce or Worcestershire sauce.

olive oil

Extra virgin olive oil adds great flavor, but you can substitute with any neutral oil like canola or sunflower oil. For a richer taste, try using butter instead.

salt

Start with a small amount and adjust to taste at the end of cooking. Consider using sea salt or kosher salt for better flavor.

pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will provide the best flavor. If you want to add a kick, consider adding a pinch of cayenne or crushed red pepper flakes.

fresh dill

Fresh dill enhances the dish significantly. If you can't find fresh, use dried dill (1/3 of the amount) but add it earlier in the cooking process.

sour cream

If you're looking for a healthier option, consider using Greek yogurt. For a dairy-free alternative, try cashew cream or coconut yogurt.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Heat the Olive Oil

    Begin by heating 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. This will create a flavorful base for your borshch.

  • Step 2: Sauté the Onions and Carrots

    Add 1 medium chopped onion and 1 large grated carrot to the pot. Sauté them together until the onion turns translucent, about 5-7 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

  • Step 3: Add the Beets

    Stir in the 2 large peeled and grated beets. Cook for an additional 5 minutes, allowing the beets to soften slightly and release their natural sweetness.

  • Step 4: Combine Remaining Ingredients

    Add in 2 medium diced potatoes, 2 cups of shredded cabbage, 2 minced garlic cloves, 2 tablespoons of tomato paste, and 4 cups of vegetable broth. Stir well to combine all the ingredients.

  • Step 5: Bring to a Boil and Simmer

    Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to a simmer. Cover the pot and let it simmer for about 40 minutes or until all the vegetables are tender.

  • Step 6: Season to Taste

    After simmering, taste the borshch and season with salt and pepper to your preference. Remember, you can always add more, but it's hard to take it out!

  • Step 7: Serve the Borshch

    Ladle the hot borshch into bowls. Garnish each bowl with fresh dill and a generous dollop of sour cream for added creaminess and flavor.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to peel and grate beets?

To peel beets, you can use a vegetable peeler or a knife. Be careful, as beet juice can stain. After peeling, use a box grater or a food processor with a grating attachment to grate the beets. If you're concerned about staining your hands, wear gloves!

How do I know when my vegetables are tender?

You can check for tenderness by piercing the vegetables with a fork. If it goes in easily, the vegetables are done. This is particularly important for potatoes and carrots, as they take longer to cook than other ingredients.

What should I do if I don't have vegetable broth?

You can substitute vegetable broth with water and add some herbs or bouillon cubes for flavor. You can also use chicken broth if you’re not strictly vegetarian.

How can I enhance the flavor of my borshch?

Adding a splash of vinegar or lemon juice can brighten the flavors. Also, consider sautéing the garlic and onions until they are golden brown for a richer taste.

What’s the best way to store leftovers?

Let your borshch cool to room temperature, then transfer it to an airtight container. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days or frozen for up to 3 months.

Is it necessary to garnish with dill and sour cream?

While it's traditional and adds great flavor, you can skip the garnish if you prefer. However, sour cream adds creaminess and dill adds freshness which enhances the overall dish.

How do I safely handle hot pots and pans?

Always use oven mitts when handling hot pots and pans. Try to keep the handles turned inward on the stove to prevent accidental spills or burns.

What if I don’t have fresh dill?

If you don’t have fresh dill, you can use dried dill instead (about 1 teaspoon). Alternatively, parsley or cilantro can also work as garnishes.

How do I properly season my borshch?

Start with a small amount of salt and pepper, then taste as you go. Remember, you can always add more, but you can’t take it out once it’s in.

What should I do if my soup is too thick?

If your borshch is too thick, simply add more vegetable broth or water until it reaches your desired consistency.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This borshch recipe is vegetarian and can easily be made vegan by substituting the sour cream with a plant-based alternative. For gluten-free options, ensure that the bread served is gluten-free, and check the ingredients of any dumplings to avoid gluten. Borshch is naturally lower in calories and rich in vegetables, making it a healthy choice for various dietary preferences.

Pairings

Borshch pairs wonderfully with crusty rye bread or garlic bread for a traditional experience. For a protein complement, consider serving it alongside Ukrainian-style varenyky (dumplings) filled with potatoes or cheese. As for beverages, a light, crisp white wine such as Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing Kvass (a traditional fermented beverage) can elevate the meal.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the borshch hot in deep bowls, ensuring each serving is garnished with a generous dollop of sour cream and a sprinkle of fresh dill. For a more rustic presentation, consider using traditional Ukrainian wooden bowls. Accompany the dish with a side of pickled vegetables for added flavor and texture.

#

Borshch

75 min
$10
250 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 4

Dietary Tags:

vegetariangluten-free

Cuisine:

UkrainianEastern European

Course:

mainstarter

Tags:

soupcomfort foodEastern European

Description

A hearty and vibrant beet soup that warms the soul with its rich flavors and natural sweetness.

Ingredients

  • beets: 2 large, peeled and grated
  • cabbage: 2 cups, shredded
  • potatoes: 2 medium, diced
  • carrots: 1 large, grated
  • onion: 1 medium, chopped
  • garlic: 2 cloves, minced
  • tomato paste: 2 tablespoons
  • vegetable broth: 4 cups
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste
  • fresh dill: for garnish
  • sour cream: for serving

Date Created:

11/17/2024
